column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/bowles-on-tush-push/|Todd Bowles Wants To Keep The Tush Push|At the Indiana Convention Center
column2: a lot of buzz has been stirred up by one play: The tush push. The Packers filed formal paperwork to have the league vote to ban the Eagles’ famous rugby-like play
column3: which for others is a quarterback sneak. It’s very effective because Eagles quarterback Jalen Hurts is such a strong
column4: tough runner and Philadelphia has a very physical offensive line. Since it came out that the Packers want to ban it
column6: head coaches of the Dixie Chicks and Bills
column8: are forcefully whining about it. McDermott even reached for the lazy excuse that the play is too dangerous for football players. Why? What evidence is there that players are being wheeled off the field right and left due to the play? McDermott didn’t provide any intel. Joe found it interesting that so far
column9: the two most vocal coaches against the tush push while speaking at the combine are both defensive guys. Well
column10: not all defensive guys are against the tush push. Enter Bucs coach Todd Bowles. Maybe because the Bucs have had decent luck against the tush push
column11: Bowles all but said it’s up to defensive coaches to devise a way to stop it. “I think it is a rugby element
column13: when a team gets something that they are good at
column15: ” Bowles said. “I don’t think the first thing you have to do is take it out of the ballgame. “That takes away the creativity [of offenses]. We have to learn how to stop it. Until we learn how to stop it they will continue — if it is not broke
column16: don’t fix it. “It’s a good challenge for defensive coaches. You just have to figure it out.” Well
column17: it helps to have physical players on your defensive line to stop it and the Bucs have that. Former Philadelphia center Jason Kelce remarked how brutal it is for a center on that play to try to push back Vita Vea. If there is any human in the NFL built to stop the tush push
column18: it’s the human wrecking ball Vea. Joe agrees with Bowles. McDermott
column20: the Packers and others are whining because they can’t stop it. So they want it banned. column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/could-the-bucs-be-preparing-for-life-after-chris-godwin/|Could The Bucs Be Preparing For Life After Chris Godwin?|Joe didn’t like the vibe from Bucs types yesterday at the combine inside the NFL beehive that is the Indiana Convention Center.  That bad vibe came when they were talking about Chris Godwin. The Bucs love Godwin but his dislocated ankle suffered against the Crows in October seems to have the team at least a little bit concerned. It’s a major injury without question. Will Godwin be the old Godwin when he’s able to return to the field — if he returns to the field? Bucs coach Todd Bowles rattled off four areas that he is focusing on improving the team. Edge rush
column3: secondary and wide receiver. If the Bucs were confident about Godwin’s return
column4: why focus on receiver? Then Joe read a mock draft from an awful mocker
column5: Bucky Brooks of NFL Network. Joe simply doesn’t care for mock drafts unless it is the last one a mocker does before the actual draft. Besides
column6: too many of these guys have cavalier attitudes and openly scoff at striving for accuracy. So why should Joe pay five seconds of attention to your nonsense if you’re not trying to be accurate? What’s the point? However
column7: in Brooks’ mock he had the Bucs selecting Ohio State receiver Emeka Egbuka at No. 19. This Egbuka is a Godwin clone. Anyone who has watched the Buckeyes the past two years has seen that. Egbuka is reliable; he loves to block in the run game and he’s tough as hell. Just like Godwin is. That got Joe thinking: The draft is deep at edge rusher. Maybe Bucs AC/DC-loving general manager Licht thinks he can draft the next Godwin at No. 19 and still get an edge rusher in the second round? Bowles mentioned yesterday that there are all kinds of talented players at inside linebacker; they’re just getting pushed down in the draft by receivers and edge rushers. Look

column2: Bucs AC/DC-loving general manager Jason Licht went through the media car wash at the combine held at the Indiana Convention Center in downtown Indianapolis. First

column7: curator and overall guru of Pro Football Talk
column9: along with Simms. Pleasantries were barely finished when Simms came right out and said it. “Why do you keep losing OCs?” Simms blurted. That’s sort of a trick question. What’s Licht to say

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/liam-coen-addresses-josh-grizzard-hire/|Liam Coen Addresses Josh Grizzard Hire|So yesterday
column2: Liam “El Serpiente” Coen told Joe that he’s been cool with JoeBucsFan.com giving him a hard time and
column4: he doesn’t even consider it a hard time.  That was cool. Joe had a private chat with Coen but also asked him on the record about the Bucs replacing him with Josh Grizzard. Coen hired Grizzard from the Dolphins last offseason. In Miami
column5: Grizzard was a quality control coach for two seasons under Mike McDaniel. In Tampa
column6: Grizzard got to be a daily voice in the crafting of the Bucs offense as passing game coordinator. Coen says Grizzard is more than ready for many reasons. “Josh is going to do a phenomenal job

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/bucs-want-kyle-trask-to-return-for-a-fifth-season/|Bucs Want Kyle Trask To Return For A Fifth Season|Fan favorite Kyle Trask also is a favorite among the powers at One Buc Palace. Speaking independently at the NFL Scouting Combine yesterday
column2: head coach Todd Bowles and Buccaneers Ring of Honor general manager Jason Licht each said they want to re-sign Trask for his fifth season in pewter and red. Trask spent two years as the No. 3 quarterback behind Tom Brady and the past two as Baker Mayfield’s backup. Trask hasn’t started a game and has thrown 11 passes. Still
column3: he’s shown his bosses enough. Licht was unsure the two sides could/would get a deal done. Bowles and Licht each said Trask might be looking for a greater chance to play. Joe was focused on the body language when Licht and Bowles talked about Trask.
